nodes.title: I.1. Residential Structures Occupying Summits: Fortresses, breastworks, religious buildings, palaces, and related edifices
General site characteristics
nodes.body: The small hilltop fasthold of spu rog mkhar is situated 40 m above the left or south side of the senge ge gtsang po (Upper Indus river) valley. It occupies a secure location with good views of the Indus valley. The hilltop and ruins are made from a light-colored stone with prominent black grains, causing the site to be either black or nearly white, depending on light conditions. True to its name, a flock of crows inhabits the locale. There were hree buildings on the summit that are now reduced to their foundations. These foundations are set on prominent revetments, 75 cm to 1.5 m in height. The foundations and revetments were constructed of mud-mortared coursed-rubble. Walls are 60 cm to 70 cm in thickness. These types of structures could only have supported wooden roofs.

nodes.title: Oral tradition
nodes.body: According to some local reports, Crow Castle was an imperial period facility.

nodes.title: North building
nodes.body: The north building may, in fact, have been two separate buildings that followed the contour of the ridge-top. Freestanding walls are only 50 cm in height. This structure measures 4.8 m (north-south) x 19 m (east-west) and seems to have contained three large rooms. If there were additional subdivisions of the interior space, the wall partitions have been totally demolished. The east room is set at a slightly lower elevation than the rest of the structure.

nodes.title: Central building
nodes.body: The central building is located 8.7 m to the west of the north building. It measures 14 m (north-south) x 3.5 m (north half) and 4.8 m (south half). It appears to have been divided into three rooms or sections. The most southerly part of the structure is not as well preserved as the rest of the building.

nodes.title: South building
nodes.body: The south building is located adjacent to the central building at 2 m higher elevation. It measures 7.2 m (east-west) x 6.5 m (east wall) and 5.4 m (west wall). Freestanding walls have been reduced to 50 cm or less in height. In this structure there is a flag mast (darchokdar lcog) for the local territorial deity (territorial deity) of Langchu LungGlang chu gling.
